title: Lawmakers toppled the French government. What happens now?
summary: With the success of a motion of no confidence against Prime Minister Michel Barnier's government, the period of political uncertainty is set to intensify.

title: French government toppled in historic no-confidence vote
summary: A majority of lawmakers voted on Wednesday for a motion of no confidence, causing the fall of Michel Barnier's three-months-old government.

title: Le Pen's questionable art of the deal
summary: By asserting that her group would vote in favor of the motion of no-confidence tabled by the left, despite the concessions obtained from the prime minister, the far-right leader runs the risk of alienating the right-wing electorate she covets.

title: 'French PM Barnier became the unfortunate guinea pig of an ungovernable Assemblée Nationale'
summary: The distrust that has permeated at all levels of the political spectrum since the prime minister's appointment explains the vote of no-confidence he faces, writes Le Monde's political columnist Françoise Fressoz.

title: Notre-Dame could have collapsed in April 2019. Here's how firefighters saved the cathedral from total destruction
summary: On April 15, 2019, the roof and spire of the famous Paris monument went up in smoke. It was a disaster, but one that could have been far worse. Using exclusive 3D modeling to reconstruct the fire, Le Monde identified the crucial decision that saved the monument.

title: In China, the authorities' intrusive canvassing to encourage women to have children
summary: Faced with a declining birth rate that no longer enables the renewal of generations, local officials are harassing women of childbearing age by telephone. A complete reversal of the one-child dogma.

title: Mexican troops seize over 2000 pounds of fentanyl in biggest catch in country's history, officials say
summary: Mexico’s top security official said soldiers and marines late Tuesday spotted two men carrying guns in the northern state of Sinaloa. They chased the men into two houses, where soldiers found about 660 pounds (300 kilograms) of fentanyl in one, and in the other a truck packed with about 1,750 pounds (800 kilograms) of the drug, mostly in pill form.

title: Ukraine pushes for NATO invitation, its members work on other guarantees
summary: Kyiv would like a formal 'invitation' to join the Alliance before Trump's inauguration in 2025, but its divided members remain cautious.

title: French Navy rescues 85 migrants trying to cross the Channel
summary: More than 70 migrants have died trying to cross the Channel to Britain this year, according to the Pas-de-Calais authorities. Tens of thousands more have reached Britain, whose government has vowed to crack down on people-smuggling gangs.

title: Paris zinc roofers earn UNESCO cultural heritage status
summary: For some 6,000 roofers in Paris, their inclusion on the list is a 'source of pride,' said Gilles Mermet, who organized the UNESCO application.

title: Bird flu in North America is worrying epidemiologists: Three people have been infected by the H5N1 virus with no source of contamination detected
summary: A teenager in Canada and a child in California have fallen ill without knowing how, after a first person in Missouri. Epidemiologists fear a low-level circulation of the virus that is causing an epizootic among dairy cows in the US.

title: Two Le Monde journalists awarded top journalism prize
summary: Lorraine de Foucher, in the print media category, and Martin Untersinger, for books, share the honor of the prestigious Prix Albert Londres with Antoine Védeilhé and Germain Baslé, for video.

title: Gender stereotypes in France widen gap between boys and girls in math
summary: An international survey unveiled on December 4, found that France is the country with the biggest performance gap between girls and boys in mathematics in the fourth grade.

title: Pogba trial: The struggles of an older brother less gifted than his football star sibling
summary: Paul Pogba's brother, who was questioned at length on Tuesday by a Paris court for his involvement in the attempted €13 million extortion from the former international athlete, said he had been 'manipulated.'

title: Iran releases Nobel Peace laureate Narges Mohammadi on medical leave
summary: Narges Mohammadi's lawyer said the Nobel Peace laureate was released for three weeks on medical grounds on Wednesday.

title: RFK Jr. wants to ban common yet controversial practice of adding fluoride to drinking water
summary: Nearly 63% of Americans have access to tap water supplemented with fluoride to fight cavities. As an increasing number of studies question the relevance of this practice, the incoming Republican administration intends to oppose it.

title: China bans the sale of certain rare metals to the US
summary: The Chinese government has announced that it will no longer issue export licenses for rare earths such as gallium, germanium and antimony to the United States. This marks a new chapter in the technological war between the world's two leading powers.

title: Trump names billionaire private astronaut Jared Isaacman as next NASA chief
summary: The 41-year-old founder and CEO of Shift4 Payments, has emerged as a leading figure in commercial spaceflight through his high-profile collaborations with SpaceX.

title: UnitedHealthcare CEO fatally shot in New York City
summary: Brian Thompson was killed Wednesday morning in what investigators suspect was a targeted shooting outside a Manhattan hotel where the company was holding an investor conference.

title: Kremlin seeks to erase the memory of Soviet repression
summary: Moscow's Gulag History Museum has closed, and, throughout Russia, statues of Stalin are multiplying as the Kremlin seeks to reshape historical memory.

title: South Korea president clings to power after martial law U-turn
summary: Lawmakers formally presented the impeachment motion in the early hours of Thursday, saying President Yoon Suk Yeol's decision to impose martial law was intended to 'evade imminent investigations ... into alleged illegal acts involving himself and his family.'

title: Belgian state condemned for crimes against humanity during Congo colonization
summary: The Brussels Court of Appeal has ruled in favor of five women born to a black mother and a white father. As children, they were abducted, placed in religious institutions and then abandoned to their fate upon the country's independence in 1960.

title: Bitcoin hits $100,000 for first time as Trump announces crypto backer Paul Atkins for SEC pick
summary: The digital unit has jumped more than 50% since Trump's poll win – and around 140% since the turn of the year. Atkins, an SEC commissioner from 2002 to 2008, founded risk consultancy firm Patomak Global Partners in 2009, whose clients include companies in the banking, trading and cryptocurrency industries.

title: French PM to submit government's resignation, Macron will address the nation on Thursday evening
summary: The French president will make a televised adress at 8 pm local time following the toppling of Prime Minister Michel Barnier's government on Wednesday.

title: Barnier's downfall: The day of a foregone failure
summary: The left and the far right came together to overthrow the shortest-serving prime minister in the French Fifth Republic.

title: Michel Barnier breaks record for shortest-serving prime minister in French Fifth Republic
summary: Barnier lasted just 90 days before being toppled by a motion of no confidence, becoming only the second prime minister to lose such a vote since the Fifth Republic was established in 1958.

title: Paris stock market climbs despite government collapse
summary: The Paris CAC 40 index won 0.4% to 7,328.79 points and the euro advanced 0.3% versus the dollar on Thursday morning.

title: Trump's controversial appointments raise questions about the future of US security
summary: To head up the FBI, the Pentagon and the intelligence services, the American president-elect has chosen three individuals – Kash Patel, Pete Hegseth and Tulsi Gabbard – whose incompetence would seem to put America in serious danger.

title: Barnier's fall puts Macron back in spotlight, but under pressure from his allies
summary: Following the topping of Prime Minister Michel Barnier's government, President Emmanuel Macron is looking to solve an unprecedented power vacuum amid the budget debate, while facing calls from the opposition to resign.

title: France risks an institutional crisis
summary: The failure of Prime Minister Michel Barnier's government reflects France's struggle to adopt a culture of compromise. Between now and June 2025 – when the Assemblée Nationale can be dissolved again – two dangers must be avoided: gridlock and the growing influence of the far right.

title: Anders Fogh Rasmussen, former NATO secretary general: 'Reversing the European Green Deal would be a geopolitical mistake'
summary: Europe's leaders must recognize that the fight against climate change is a security priority, not just an environmental concern, stresses the former Danish prime minister.

title: Financial markets' response measured after French government collapse
summary: Prime Minister Michel Barnier's downfall has heightened concerns among investors.

title: Paul McCartney cuts a fine figure at Paris concert
summary: On his Got Back tour, the former Beatle stopped off in Paris to play hits from The Beatles to Wings to a full house in Europe's largest indoor venue.

title: 'Wicked': Two witches united in an irresistible spectacle
summary: Jon M. Chu succeeds in his adaptation by retaining the spirit of the famous original musical and relying on off-beat humor.

title: Amnesty International accuses Israel of 'genocide' in Gaza
summary: The London-based rights organization said its findings were based on satellite images documenting devastation, fieldwork and ground reports from Gazans as well as 'dehumanizing and genocidal statements by Israeli government and military officials.'

title: Islamist-led rebels capture key Syrian city of Hama
summary: The rebels led by the Islamist group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham overran forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad only days after capturing Aleppo in a lightning offensive.

title: EU's von der Leyen to attend Notre Dame re-opening
summary: Ursula von der Leyen will be in Paris on Saturday, December 7, for the reopening ceremony of the famous cathedral, along with around 50 other world leaders, including Donald Trump.

title: Le Pen defends decision to topple French government as 'reasonable'
summary: Marine Le Pen and her MPs sought to downplay the consequences of a decision that is worrying its supporters, and even those within their own ranks.

title: Mercosur free-trade agreement: Ursula von der Leyen's imminent decision to sign the deal marks the retreat of French influence
summary: The Commission president is on her way to Montevideo, Uruguay, for the Mercosur summit, where she could ratify the treaty despite Paris's categorical and repeated opposition.

title: Tbilisi's population clashes with government: 'The only option now in Georgia is revolution'
summary: Protesters across 42 cities are demonstrating against the government's suspension of the EU accession process until 2028 and the results of the parliamentary elections, which the president has not recognized.

title: Notre-Dame's 340,000 donors
summary: 'The story of Notre-Dame' (3/5). Two days after the April 15, 2019 fire, pledges to rebuild the Paris cathedral had already amounted to €900 million. After five years of restoration work, the reopening, on December 7 and 8, will honor the largest donors, alongside heads of state.

title: In India, the Adani empire is faltering
summary: Built with the unwavering support of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, businessman Gautam Adani's conglomerate, estimated to be worth over $56 billion, is under investigation by the US justice system for corruption.

title: Bahamas rejects Trump proposal to take deported migrants
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's team has drawn up a list of countries to which it wants to deport migrants when their home countries refuse to accept them, according to NBC News.

title: Georgian President Salomé Zourabichvili: 'This is a vital moment for the country, and I hope the outcome will not be tragic'
summary: In an interview with Le Monde, the pro-European president of the former Soviet republic in the Caucasus said that the pro-Russian ruling party, Georgian Dream, is today 'very isolated.'

title: Cuba restores power grid and resumes planned blackouts of about 5 hours a day
summary: The latest blackout, the third one of this severity in less than two months, occurred in the early hours of Wednesday, after a breakdown at a thermoelectric plant in Matanzas province, east of Havana.

title: Macron says he'll name new PM in the next few days, vows to remain in office
summary: The French president spoke after the resignation of Prime Minister Michel Barnier, whose government was toppled by a no-confidence vote in Parliament.
